ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live/recorded lecture

Lectures are recorded for future references. Weekly hour-long mandatory presentation/discussion section with the entire class. At least two teaching assistants that could be easily contacted. No psets but three projects/presentations total, the first two of which were arbitrarily assigned to random groups of 4-5. The final project was more flexible and we had the option of forming groups of 3-7 people.
Live lecture over zoom was pretty much it.
Weekly virtual discussion sections
Problem Session once a week where a group of students go through a set of questions
Problem sets and projects
I would often go back to recorded lectures if there was something I missed during live lecture.
Group projects facilitated learning by allowing for discussions between different students.
Nothing else.
None
Live virtual lectures that were also available as recorded lectures after each class.
Monday meeting presentations for homework assignments and midterm projects
none
none
Additional synchronous sections on Mondays.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned some analysis

I learned about the main topics in real analysis, with a frequent reference to their applications in computer science, economics, statistics, physics, etc. It was also my first time making math presentation and writing math reports.
Some topics in analysis and some interesting applications, such as Brownian motion and random walks, martingales, tent functions, etc.

I learned some things about sequences of functions and function spaces, although into as much as I expected. I did not really learn all that much in this class, and coming from 230-231, I feel as if I could have comfortably skipped this class and gone on to 305 directly.

Unfortunately, very few. I found that the lectures were hard to follow. I was often confused what topic we were discussing and what problem we were trying to solve. The notation was often unclear and inconsistent, and I generally struggled to keep up. That said, Peter Jones is super kind and engaged. He clearly cares a lot about his students and their learning.
Skills in analysis
Proofs

I learned about metric spaces, what makes a good metric, concepts of Cauchy sequences, compactness and completeness, related theorems that exploit those concepts to give interesting results such as the Banach Fixed Point theorem, Brownian Motion, Weierstrass theorems etc...
Learned about some basic techniques in real analysis and the some of the history of analysis.
I didnt really learn anything. The lectures felt disorganized and unconnected to each other.
I learned a lot about real analysis, its applications to the real world, and how to think mathematically.
I deepened my skills in analysis, while exploring various topics of interest including RANN algorithms

The basic history of functional analysis and advanced applications of functional analysis. Norms, metric spaces, fixed point theorems, non-differential continuous functions, Brouwer's fixed point theorem, Brownian motion.
I learned about many famous/important proofs and theorems used in Analysis, and also learned to prove some of them myself.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More homework exercises are needed to help understand and solidify lecture content.

Although I liked the instructor, I feel like there just wasn't a lot of structure to the class. I had difficulty understanding the importance of the different things we were learning and their applicability to different math problems. The fact that this class had no consistent homework made it difficult for me to put theory into practice.

I think having psets or at least practice problems here and there would have helped me digest the material better. But I also do think the focus on presentation and teamwork challenged me a lot (I learned LaTeX for this class and I'm forever grateful!!).

The topics were interesting and the project-based format was a unique and fun way to learn them. We were divided into groups for the midterm and final and worked on a few problems together as a group and then presented it to the class. It was definitely more engaging than doing a regular pset. 
Weaknesses -- it's sometimes hard to understand Professor Jones' teaching style and honestly, it was very hard to stay engaged with the class throughout the semester and I didn't learn that much.

One weakness of this course is that there was not weekly homework. This can make it hard to really apply the material and learn it well, and you kind of just move along passively with the course until it is your turn to do a weekly homework.

Strengths: group projects are great for solidifying knowledge of certain material / problems. I think it's great to avoid exams in the online format because they are not conducive to learning. peter jones is super super kind and caring and open to meeting with students individually. 

Weaknesses: very poor lectures. Textbook sucked. didn't receive any feedback or grades the whole class.
The lectures could have a little more structure. Sometimes they are hard to follow

Great professor
Challenging but doable 
Not much weekly work

Strengths- easy grading, self guided, slow paced

Weakness: Could have a little more pressure

The strengths of the course consist of a good level of interaction thanks to the virtual whiteboard, interesting presentation sessions where one can learn of applications of certain theorems and work with other members of the class. It was probably the one class I had this semester where I met most of the people in the class and had to collaborate with them on a presentation.

I'm sure this course is taught very differently during a normal, in-person semester, but it just didn't work this time around. The only assignments I was ever given were two group projects (for which I never received feedback or a grade), and the lack of graded weekly p-sets meant most students got by without having to learn analysis (me included, to my shame). But really, what do you expect when students have other hard classes with regular assignments, as well as all the other commitments we typically make -- most of us need grades as a motivator (even just for completion). Now, the projects were pretty interesting, but I do not feel even remotely prepared for Math 305, which I was looking forward to taking next semester. All this said, the professor is really sweet and clearly enjoys teaching. I guess he just didn't think any of this through when planning this class.

Honestly, I was very disappointed by this course. The lack of structure and very confusing notes the written by the professor made it impossible to build a strong foundation of analysis. I plan to take Math 305 next semester, but feel in no way feel that 301 somehow prepared me for it. If you're a math major, or just someone looking to learn higher level math, I'd recommend skipping this course and taking something more engaging. The only "upside" was the workload was incredibly low, if you absolutely need this course for whatever reason. But, overall, stay away from this course.

Maybe it was just because it was online, but this class had basically no strengths and plenty of weaknesses. Professor Jones repeated himself often, and the course didnt really feel like it had any kind of progression.

I think the strength of this course is definitely Professor Jones, who is highly enthusiastic and has a wonderful sense of humor. The course could have been improved by adding more small assessments (ex: homework submissions).
This course is a great exploratory math course for someone looking for a reasonably low-workload pure math class
Professor Jones cares a lot about his students and is always willing to help. He is very kind and made mathematics interesting. I think the course can be improved if the lectures were more organized.

The subject material was fascinating and well-chosen. I feel like I learned about exactly what I was hoping to. It was difficult to learn in an online environment, but that was inevitable for this semester.

The instructor worked with students on their projects, and this was very helpful in pointing the students in the right direction for the proofs. The class goes over a lot of historical and famous proofs, and the professor is enthusiastic about math and its history.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We had the option to meet with either the TAs or the Professor outside of classtime to discuss anything, so I felt pretty engaged and supported throughout the semester. Maybe the presentation sessions could have been more lively.
Having a live lecture format was helpful so that we could ask questions as we went along. Office hours were also helpful.
I think the live lectures worked well.
Professor Jones did a great job of using the whiteboard function to lecture and was happy to meet with anyone during office hours!
Yes, great online teaching

The presentations were definitely engaging and maintained interest in the class. The use of a virtual whiteboard was useful to visualize most things at times, but it could be useful to standardize virtual teaching methods in the math department and provide training. Sometimes, I would get lost as to where the Professor was pointing at due to the absence of a pointer on the screen. The class itself often times lacked structure and did not follow the textbook. It would then be easy for me to get lost as to where we were going next.

This class had very low engagement, even compared to my other remote classes this semester. The professor essentially just talked about whatever analysis topic he felt like, writing down notes on a tablet as though he were jotting things down for himself to remember later. His stories were sometimes interesting, but the most common emotion I felt during this class was an overwhelming sense of frustration at the lack of substance I was being taught.
The online lectures were just really not engaging at all.
I thought lectures could have been slightly more engaging, but I really liked the group projects
It is nice that we had group assignments instead of exams. This help me to learn more about whats required of thinking through and communicating complex math proofs rather than memorising proofs.
I think Professor Jones did an excellent job adapting his course for the required online learning we had to participate in.

I think the course was adapted well. The professor was willing to meet with students for projects or other questions, and had little trouble lecturing over Zoom. The course may benefit from the professor offering a longer, open office hour where he perhaps reviews difficult topics or goes into some things a bit more in-depth.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Weekly homework assignments were only assigned to random groups of students, who would then present the problems to class during section. Some students were never assigned homework, by luck of the draw. A lot of hand-holding from Prof. Jones and TFs on homeworks and midterm/final projects.
Not really. Unless this is required for your major, definitely don't take it. I didn't learn analysis at all, and there was so little work that I didn't need to make the effort to learn anything.

It depends on what you are looking for. If you have taken 230-231, I would not really recommend this course. The first half is just a repetition of what you already learned, and the second half becomes a somewhat random assortment of topics without following a particularly obvious train of thought. If you have not taken 230-231 and have never seen the topics of the first half, then the course is probably a good introduction to a lot of those topics.
I can't recommend this class on the expectation that you learn analysis. I don't think I learned any analysis, and I wouldn't pass any examination on the topics.
Yeah its a very differently structured math class but its kinda fun to learn in a different way.

If you are willing to get familiar with all material by yourself first, and then attend lectures to get an additional insight and ask questions this is a very good course. The professor is extremely knowledgable and can explain all the details very well. But if you want to learn the material from scratch just from attending lectures and doing no readings from the textbook, I don't really think this is a good course for you.
Yes. I honestly think this class is a better alternative to Math 300. It might be harder concepts but there is no testing and 2 group projects which make this significantly easier
Yes, nice and easy introduction to analysis

I would recommend this course to students who have had some experience with proofs previously and who are used to a relatively fast pace of teaching. The course provides a nice introduction to analysis concepts but it is important to stay on top of previous concepts to understand new ones being taught. The class sometimes lacks structure and does not necessarily follow the textbook so it is important to attend the classes.
Provided it's in-person and you actually have tests and homework to keep you accountable, yes. Otherwise, you're wasting your time.

Professor Jones is clearly passionate and invested in teaching the material. However, lectures are disconnected and very difficult to follow. Don't take this course unless you are willing to re-learn the material.

I would absolutely recommend this course to other students. It is perfect for someone wanting to explore higher math topics but worried about their own abilities. Any student will thrive because of the way assignments are completed.
No, for reasons described above.
Well, I didnt learn any analysis but it also didnt require any work. The entire class was just three group projects and no homework.
I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in mathematics beyond multivariable calculus.
Yes! If you are looking for a low-workload, interesting pure math course, this is a great option
Yes. Professor Jones is a great teacher. However, be prepared to be self-motivated in unpacking the material communicated in lectures and asking questions.
Yes, this is a necessary course for many fields.
Yes; it is nice to work on projects with others and to learn how to do longer, more involved proofs. The course also covers a lot of mathematical topics that are good to know about.
